rules.definition: Depression is a mood disorder that causes persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and loss of interest. Depression is a decline in mood that persists for an extended period, represents a decrease from a previous level of function, and causes some impairment in function. Depression contributes significantly to the global burden of disease affecting an estimated 350 million people worldwide. In many cultures depression is expressed commonly as somatic or physical complaints (e.g. fatigue, generalized pain, digestive problems, headache).
rules.treatment: Consult with a mental health professional for therapy and possibly medication if symptoms are persistent and severe, refer to a crisis center/doctor/hospital for further evaluation, diagnosis, & treatment. Engage in regular physical activity, maintain a healthy diet, and stay connected with supportive friends and family. Offer support: emphasize that there is no shame in feeling depressed to get help the individual identify others who can serve as support (family, friends) help him/her identify & focus on personal strengths and the positives in a challenging situation help him/her identify & focus on what they can control ask about hopeless and suicidal feelings and the intent to act on these feelings.

rules.definition: Anxiety is a general feeling of unease, worry, and uneasiness. It can be triggered by a variety of feelings, behaviors, and thoughts. Anxiety may be defined as a state of neurological arousal characterized by both physical and psychological signs. Anxiety may be a normal reaction that acts as a signal to the body that aspects of its systems are under stress. Prevalence estimates of anxiety disorders are generally higher in developed countries than in developing countries according to global mental health survey data. The specific neuro-biological mechanisms underlying anxiety are complex and may involve genetic, biological, and psychological factors.
rules.treatment: Consider cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or other therapeutic approaches. Practice relaxation techniques like deep breathing, mindfulness, or yoga. Regular exercise and a balanced diet are also beneficial.

rules.definition: Psychosis is a severe mental disorder in which thought and emotions are so impaired that contact is lost with external reality. Psychosis can occur in various mental illnesses, including schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and severe depression. Symptoms may include hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, and impaired perception. Psychosis can significantly impair a person's ability to function in daily life and may require immediate medical attention.
rules.treatment: Seek immediate help from a mental health professional, crisis hotline, or emergency services. Do not hesitate to reach out to friends, family, or trusted individuals for support.

conditions: Grief from loss of family members
rules.definition: Grief is a feeling of loss and sadness over the loss of someone close to you.
rules.treatment: Seek support from a grief counselor or support group. Allow yourself to mourn and express your emotions. Engage in self-care activities and lean on friends and family for support.

rules.definition: Stress is a state of mind characterized by anxiety, worry, and a lack of energy.
rules.treatment: Identify and address the sources of stress, if possible. Practice relaxation techniques such as meditation, deep breathing, and yoga. Seek support from a mental health professional if needed.

rules.definition: Schizophrenia is a serious mental disorder in which people interpret reality abnormally. Schizophrenia may result in some combination of hallucinations, delusions, and extremely disordered thinking and behavior that impairs daily functioning. Schizophrenia is a chronic disorder that may be characterized by a decline in motivation, socialization and function, diminished emotional expression, disorganized or abnormal motor behavior (physical movement) and distorted sense of reality (with disturbances in perception or the expression of thought). Theories regarding the cause have been proposed and have included a genetic, biological, psychosocial, and infectious basis for the disease.
rules.treatment: Consult with a psychiatrist for proper diagnosis and treatment. Antipsychotic medications, along with therapy, are commonly used to manage symptoms. Support from family and friends is crucial.

rules.definition: Eating disorders are a group of mental health conditions that affect how you eat and think about food.
rules.treatment: Consult with a healthcare provider or mental health specialist specializing in eating disorders. Engage in therapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or nutritional counseling. Establish a healthy eating routine and seek support from trusted individuals.

rules.definition: Bipolar disorder is a type of mood disorder characterized by distinct phases of sustained depression and/or distinct periods of a mood which is persistent and abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable. Psychosis may be present also in either phase.

rules.definition: Dependence (addiction) — continued desire for and use of a psychoactive substance to satisfy pleasurable urges and/or to alleviate the effects of withdrawal. Dependence may be psychological or physical in nature. Worldwide, alcohol consumption and problems related to alcohol vary widely, but, in most countries, the burden of disease and death remains significant. Alcohol consumption is the world’s third-largest risk factor for disease and disability behind high blood pressure (first) and smoking (second). In middle-income countries, it is the greatest risk.
rules.treatment: Refer to medical evaluation, diagnosis, & medical stabilization as indicated. Assess for underlying psychiatric conditions (e.g., depression, anxiety). Refer to a drug counseling program if available or psychological services for treatment. Evaluate and provide or refer to appropriate treatments for underlying psychiatric conditions. Encourage individuals to identify people who can provide support when cravings or distress occur.

conditions: Destabilization and abnormal stimulation of nervous system cells
rules.definition: Epilepsy is a chronic disorder of the brain affecting approximately 50 million people worldwide, with nearly 80% of the people with epilepsy found in developing countries. The condition is characterized by recurrent seizures (i.e., brief episodes of involuntary shaking) which may involve a part of the body (partial) or the entire body (generalized). Seizures are due to excessive electrical discharges within a network of brain cells and may be accompanied by the loss of consciousness and control of bowel or bladder function.
rules.treatment: Educate family/caretakers about the signs and symptoms of epilepsy and provide guidance on what to do during a seizure. Help identify stressors and coping mechanisms. Encourage maintaining a routine and adherence to medication. Stress the importance of keeping track of appointments.
